entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:

entry.title: Trigonometric-integral
entry.content:
$$
(arcsin x)’=\frac{1}{(siny)’} \ \ \ \ \ \ \ (y=arcsin(x))
$$

$$
=\frac{1}{cos(y)}
$$

$$
=\frac {1}{\sqrt{1-(sin(y))^2}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}
$$

$$
(arccosx)’=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}
$$

$$
\int tan x dx=\int \frac{sinx}{cosx}dx
$$

$$
u=cosx \ \ \ \ du=-sinxdx
$$

$$
\int \frac{sinx}{cosx}dx=\int - \frac{1}{u}du=-ln(u)+c=-ln(cosx)+c
$$

$$
\int secx dx = \int secx \times \frac{secx+tanx}{secx +tanx}dx
$$

$$
(sec x+tanx)’=\frac{sinx}{cos^2x}+\frac{1}{cos^2x}
$$

$\int \frac{f’(x)}{f(x)}=ln(f(x))+c$
$$
\int secx dx =ln(secx+tanx)+c
$$

$$
\int \frac{dx}{x^2\sqrt{1+x^2}}
$$

$$
tanu=x
$$

$$
dx= sec^2udu
$$

$$
\int \frac{dx}{x^2\sqrt{1+x^2}}=\int \frac{sec^2udu}{tan^2u secu}=\int \frac{cosu}{sin^2u}du=\int \frac{1}{v^2}dv
$$

$$
-\frac{1}{v}+c=-\frac{1}{sinu}+c=- \sqrt\frac{x^2+1}{x^2}+c
$$

entry.title: float
entry.content:
IEEE standard:
$$
V=(-1)^S \times M \times 2^E
$$
$E$ is an unsigned int
$$
E=exp-bias
\
M=m+1 (1\le M <2)
$$
$$
(-1)^0 \times (1+2^{-2}) \times 2^{(124-127)}=0.15625
$$

entry.title: pyhtonlist
entry.content:
There are four collection data types in the Python programming language:

  • List is a collection which is ordered and changeable. Allows duplicate members.
  • Turple is a collection which is ordered and unchangeable. Allows duplicate members.
  • Set is a collection which is unordered, unchangeable, and unindexed. No duplicate members.
  • Dictionary is a collection which is ordered and changeable. No duplicate members.

$[i:]$ form the $(i+1)-th$ element to the end.

$[: -i]$ a list without the last $i$ elements

entry.title: INTERMEDIATE-VALUE-THEOREM
entry.content:
Rolle theorem:

If a function $f$ is continuous and differentiable on $[a,b]$ , $f(a)=f(b)$ ,

there exists a point $c \in[a,b]$ where $f’(c)=0$.

Example:

If $a>0$, $f(x)$ is continuous and differentiable on $[a,b]$ and $bf(a)=af(b)$ , prove that there exists a point $\zeta \in (a,b)$, where $\zeta f’(\zeta)=f(\zeta)$

Solution:
$$
\frac{f(a)}{a}=\frac{f(b)}{b}
$$
Let $g(x)=\frac{f(x)}{x} $
$$
g’(x)=\frac{xf’(x)-f(x)}{x^2}
$$
$g(a)=g(b)$

Since $f(x)$ is continuous and differentiable on $[a,b]$ and $a>0$,

$g(x)$ is continuous and differentiable on $[a,b]$

so there exists a point $\zeta$ where $g’(\zeta)=0$
$$
\zeta f’( \zeta)-f(\zeta)=0
$$
Lagrange theorem:

If $a>0$, $f(x)$ is continuous and differentiable on $[a,b]$, there exists a point on $c \in[a,b]$ such that
$$
f’(c)=\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}
$$
Cauchy theorem:

If a function $f$ is continuous and differentiable on $[a,b]$ and $g’(x)\ne 0$ whenever $x \in (a,b)$

then there exists a point $\zeta \in [a,b]$ where
$$
(f(b)-f(a))g’(\zeta)=(g(b)-g(a))f’(\zeta)
$$
Proof:

if $g(a)=g(b)$, then from Rolle theorem we can notice that

there exists a point $\zeta \in[a,b]$ where $g’(\zeta)=0$.

So $g(a) \ne g(b)$

Let $h(x)=f(x)-\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{g(b)-g(a)}g(x)$

$h(a)=\frac{f(a)g(b)-f(b)g(a)}{g(b)-g(a)}$

$h(b)=\frac{f(a)g(b)-f(b)g(a)}{g(b)-g(a)}$

$h(a)=h(b)$

so there exists a point $\zeta$ where $h’(\zeta)=0$

$h’(\zeta)=f’(\zeta)-\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{g(b)-g(a)}g’(\zeta)=0$

so there exists a point $\zeta \in [a,b]$ where
$$
(f(b)-f(a))g’(\zeta)=(g(b)-g(a))f’(\zeta)
$$

entry.title: limits
entry.content:
The precise definition of limits:

Let $f$ be a function defined on some open interval that contains the number $a$, except possibly at $a$ itself. Then we say that the limits of $f(x)$ as $x$ approaches $a$ is $L$ ,and we write
$$
lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x)=L
$$
if for every number $\epsilon >0$ there is a number $\delta>0$ such that
$$
if \ \ \ \ 0<|x-a|<\delta \ \ \ \ \ then \ \ \ \ \ |f(x)-L|<\epsilon
$$
**Definition of left-hand limit:**
$$
lim_{x \rightarrow a^{-}}f(x)=L
$$
if for every number $\epsilon>0$ there is a number $\delta>0$ such that
$$
if \ \ \ \ \ a-\delta<x<a \ \ \ \ then \ \ \ |f(x)-L|<\epsilon
$$
**Definition of right-hand limit:**
$$
lim_{x \rightarrow a^{+}}f(x)=L
$$
if for every number $\epsilon>0$ there is a number $\delta>0$ such that
$$
if \ \ \ \ \ a<x<a+\delta \ \ \ \ then \ \ \ |f(x)-L|<\epsilon
$$
Proof of the sum law

If $lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x)=L$ and $lim_{x \rightarrow a}g(x)=M$ both exists, then
$$
lim_{x \rightarrow a}[f(x)+g(x)]=L+M
$$
We should prove that for every number $\epsilon > 0$ there is a number $\delta>0$ such that
$$
if \ \ \ \ 0<|x-a|<\delta \ \ \ then \ \ \ |f(x)+g(x)-L-M|<\epsilon
$$
Notice that
$$
|f(x)+g(x)-L-M| \le |f(x)-L|+|g(x)-M|
$$
Since $lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x)=L$ and $lim_{x \rightarrow a}g(x)=M$ both exists, there exists a number $\delta_{1}>0$ such that
$$
if \ \ \ \ 0<|x-a|<\delta_{1} \ \ \ then\ \ \ |f(x)-L|<\frac{\epsilon}{2}
$$
and there exists a number $\delta_{2}>0$ such that
$$
if \ \ \ \ 0<|x-a|<\delta_{2} \ \ \ then\ \ \ |g(x)-L|<\frac{\epsilon}{2}
$$
Let $\delta=min(\delta_{1},\delta_{2})$. Notice that
$$
if \ \ \ 0<|x-a|<\delta \ \ \ then \ \ \ 0<|x-a|<\delta_{1} \ \ \ and \ \ \ 0<|x-a|<\delta_{2}
$$
so
$$
|f(x)-L|<\frac{\epsilon}{2} \ \ \ \ and \ \ \ |g(x)-L|<\frac{\epsilon}{2}
$$
Therefore
$$
|f(x)+g(x)-L-M| \le |f(x)-L|+|g(x)-M|<\epsilon
$$

Definition of infinite limits

Let $f$ be a function defined on some open interval that contains the number $a$, except possibly at $a$ it self. Then
$$
lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x)=\infty
$$
means that for every positive number $M$ there is a positive number $\delta$ such that
$$
if \ \ \ 0<|x-a|< \delta \ \ \ then \ \ f(x)>M
$$
Let $f$ be a function defined on some open interval that contains the number $a$, except possibly at $a$ it self. Then
$$
lim_{x \rightarrow a}f(x)=\infty
$$
means that for every positive number $M$ there is a positive number $\delta$ such that
$$
if \ \ \ 0<|x-a|< \delta \ \ \ then \ \ f(x)<M
$$

entry.title: determinants
entry.content:
The determinants of order $n$ is a number valued function of an ordered list of $n$ vectors $V_1,V_2 ,\dots ,V_n$ each with $n$ components. We denotes it as
$$
det(V_1,V_2,\dots, V_{n})
$$

  1. $det(V_1,V_2,\dots,V_n)$ is a multilinear function, that is , a linear function for each $V_i$, when all other $V_j, j \ne i$ are held fixed.
  2. If two vectors $V_i$ and $V_j$ of the ordered list are equal, the value of the dorminants is zero.
  3. $det(E_1,E_2, \dots , E_n)=1$, where $E_{j}$ is the vector whose $i-th$ component is 1 and all other components are zero.
  4. If two of vectors in the ordered set are interchanged, the value of the determinant is multiplied by $-1$.
  5. If $V_1,V_2,V_3 \dots,V_n$ are lineearly dependent, then $det(V_1,V_2,\dots V_{n})=0$
  6. If $V_1,V_2,V_3 \dots,V_n$ are lineearly dependent, then $det(V_1,V_2,\dots V_{n}) \ne0$

Proof of $4,5,6$:
$$
det(U+V,U+V)=det(U,U+V)+det(V,U+V)
$$

$$
=det(U,U)+det(U+V)+det(V,U)+det(V,V)
$$

$$
det(U,V)+det(V,U)=0
$$

If $V_1,V_2,V_3 \dots,V_n$ are linearly dependent, then
$$
V_1=\sum_{i=2}^{n}a_iV_i
$$

$$
det(V_1,V_2,\dots,V_n)=\sum_{i=3}^{n}det(a_iV_i,V_2,\dots,a_iV_i,\dots,V_n)+det(a_2V_2,a_2V_2,\dots,V_n)=0
$$

If $V_1,V_2,V_3 \dots,V_n$ are linearly dependent, then the unit coordinate vector $E_i$ can be expressed:
$$
E_i=\sum_{j=1}^{n}b_{ji}V_{j}
$$

$$
det(E_1,E_2,\dots,E_n)=det(\sum_{j=1}^{n}b_{j1}V_{j},E_2,\dots,E_n)
$$

$$
=\sum_{j=1}^{n}b_{j1} det(V_j,E_2,\dots,E_n)
$$

$$
=\sum_{j=1}^{n}b_{j1}\sum_{k=1}^{n}b_{k2} det(V_j,V_k,\dots,E_n)
$$

Continuing this we can get the expression
$$
det(E_1,E_2,\dots,E_n)=\sum_{permutation jk\dots z}(b_{j1}b_{k2}\dots b_{zn})det(V_j,V_k,\dots V_z)
$$
For each permutation, either
$$
det(V_j,V_k,\dots V_z)=-det(V_1,V_2,\dots,V_n)
$$
or
$$
det(V_j,V_k,\dots V_z)=det(V_1,V_2,\dots,V_n)
$$

$$
det(E_1,E_2,\dots,E_n)=1
$$

this prove (6)

Next we define the signature of permutation as follows. Donated by
$$
p=p_1 p_2\dots p_n
$$
Definition:

We define the sinature of a permutation $p$ of $1,2,\dots,n$ to be the nnumber $s(p)=1 $ or $-1$, such that
$$
\prod_{i<j}(X_{p_{i}}-x_{p_{j}})=s(p)\prod_{i<j}(x_i-x_j)
$$
$s(p)$ has following properties:

  1. The siganture of an intechange is $-1$.
  2. The signature of the composite of two permutation is the profuct is the product of the signatures $s(pq)=s(p)s(q)$

Proof:

The composite of $p$ and $q=q_1q_2\dots q_n$ can be expressed as
$$
pq=p_{q_{1}}p_{q_{2}}\dots p_{q_{n}}
$$

$$
\prod_{i<j}(x_{p_{q_{i}}}-x_{p_{q_{j}}})=\prod_{i<j}{(y_{q_i}-y_{q_j})}=s(q)\prod_{i<j}{(y_{i}-y_{j})}=s(p)s(q)\prod_{i<j}{(x_{i}-x_{j})}
$$

if we denote $x_{p_k}=y_k$ for every $k$

Definition:

Let $V_1,\dots,V_n$ be vectors in $R^n$ written as columns,

{% mathjax %}V_1=\begin{bmatrix}v_{11} \\v_{21} \\ \dots \\v_{n1}\end{bmatrix}V_2=\begin{bmatrix}v_{12} \\v_{22} \\ \dots \\v_{n2}\end{bmatrix},\dots,V_n=\begin{bmatrix}v_{1n} \\v_{2n} \\ \dots \\v_{nn}\end{bmatrix}{% endmathjax %}

The determinants is defined as
$$
det(V_1,V_2,\dots,V_n)=\sum_{p}s(p)v_{p1}v_{p2}\dots v_{pn}
$$
Example:
$$
V_1=\begin{bmatrix}
v_{11} \ v_{21} \end{bmatrix}
V_2=\begin{bmatrix}
v_{12} \ v_{22} \end{bmatrix}
$$
$s(12)=1$

$s(21)=-1$

$det(V_1,V_2)=v_{11}v_{22}-v_{21}v_{12}$

entry.title: FOO differencial-equation
entry.content:
Seperable equation:

A first order ODE has the form $F(x,y,y’)=0$.

We can integrating both sides gives
$$
\int f(y)y’dx=\int g(x)dx
$$

$$
\int f(y)dy=\int f(y) \frac{dy}{dx}dx
$$

Example:
$$
2xy+6x+(x^2-4)y’=0
$$

$$
\frac{y’}{y+3}=\frac{2x}{4-x^2}
$$

$$
ln(|y+3|)=-ln(|x^2-4|)+C
$$

$$
|y+3||x^2-4|=A
$$

$$
y+3=\frac{A}{x^2-4}
$$

Exact Different Equation:

Definition:

An expresssion of thw form $F(x,y)dx+G(x,y)dy$ is called a ($first order$) differential form. A differnential form $F(x,y)dx+G(y,x)dy$ is called exact if there exists a function $g(x,y) $ such that $dg=Fdx+Gdy$.

entry.title: linear-map
entry.content:
Definition:

Let $S$ and $T$ be two linear spaces. Let $f: S \rightarrow T$ be a transformation that associates on and only one element of $T$ to each element of $S$. The transformation $f$ is said to be a linear map if and only if
$$
f(a_1s_1+a_2s_2)=a_1f(s_1)+a_2f(s_2)
$$
for any two scalars $a_1$ and $a_2$ and any two vectors $s_1,s_2 \in S$

Proposition 1:

Let $S$ be the linear space of all $L \times 1$ column vectors. Let $T$ be the linear space of all $K \times 1$ column vectors. Let A be a $K \times L$ matrix. Consider the transformation $f : s \rightarrow T$defined,for any $s \in S$,by
$$
f(s)=As
$$
where $As$ denotes the matrix product between $A$ and $s$. Then $f$ is a linear map.

Proof:
$$
f(a_1s_1+a_2s_2)=A(a_1s_1+a_2s_2)=a_1As_1+a_2As_2=a_1f(s_1)+a_2f(s_2)
$$
the same result also hold for post-multiplication.

Let $S$ be the linear space of all $1 \times L$ column vectors. Let $T$ be the linear space of all $1\times K$ column vectors. Let A be a $K \times L$ matrix. Consider the transformation $f : s \rightarrow T$defined,for any $s \in S$,by
$$
f(s)=sA
$$
where $sA$ denotes the matrix product between $s$ and $A$.Then $f$ is a linear map.

Proposition 2:

Let $a_1,\dots,a_K$ be $K$ scalars and let $s_1, \dots ,s_K$ be $K$ elements of a linear space $S$. If $S \rightarrow T$ is a linear map, then
$$
f(\sum_{i=1}^{K}a_is_i)=\sum_{i=1}^{K}a_{i}f(s_{i})
$$

entry.title: triangular-matrix
entry.content:
Definition:

A $K \times K$ matrix L is a lower triangular matrix if $L_{i,j}=0$ whenever $i<j$.

A $K \times K$ matrix L is an upper triangular matrix if $L_{i,j}=0$ whenever $i>j$.

Proposition 1:

The transpose of a triangular matrix is also triangular.

Proposition 2:

the product of two triangular matrices is triangular.

Proof (the product of two lower matrices is triangular):

Suppose $A$ and $B$ are two upper triangular matrices.

We need to prove that $(AB)_{i,j}=0$ when $i>j$.

{% mathjax %}(AB)_{i,j}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}(A_{i,k}B_{k,j})=\sum_{k=i}^{K}(A_{i,k}B_{k,j})=0{% endmathjax %}

if $A_{i,j}=0$ and $B_{i,j}=0$ whenever $i>j$

Proposition 3:

A triangular matrix is invertible if and only if its diagonal entries are non-zero.

Proof (part 1):

If the diagonal entries of a lower-triangular matrix are non-zero, then it is invertible.

We can prove this by contradiction.

Suppose this $ K \times K$matrix is singular when its diagonal entries are non-zero.

$L_{k}= a_1L_1+ \dots a_{k-1}L_{k-1}+a_{k+1}L_{k+1} \dots a_{K}L_{K}$

$a_{K}=0$ because $K^{th}$ row is the only row that has a non-zero entry in $K^{th}$ column.

$L_{k}= a_1L_1+ \dots a_{k-1}L_{k-1}+a_{k+1}L_{k+1} + \dots +a_{K-1}L_{K-1} $

$a_{K-1}=0$

Repeat this until we deduce that $a_{k+1}=a_{k+2}=\dots=a_K=0$

the $k^{th}$ entry of the main diagonal is zero.

this’s impossible since the $k^{th}$ entry of the main diagonal is non-zero

Proof (part 2):

A lower-triangular matrix $L$ is invertible if its diagonal entries are non-zero.

Suppose the $k^{th}$ entry of the diagonal of matrix $L$ is zero.

Consider a $k \times k$ matrix that is formed by the first $k$ rows of $L$.

this matrix has at most $k-1$ independent rows.

As a consequence, the $k$ rows of the matrix are not independent.

$L$ is not full-ranked and is not invertible.

Proposition 4:

If a lower (upper) triangular $K \times K$ matrix $L$ is invertible, then its inverse is lower (upper) triangular. Furthermore, each entry on the main diagonal of $L^{-1}$ satisfies

{% mathjax %}(L^{-1})_{kk}=\frac{1}{L_{kk}}{% endmathjax %}

entry.title: sum-of-subspaces
entry.content:
Definition:

Let $S$ be a linear space and $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ are two subspaces of $S$. The sum of $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ is the set

{% mathjax %}S_{1}+S_{2}= \{ s=s_{1}+s_{2}| s_{1} \in S_{1} s_{2} \in S_{2}\}{% endmathjax %}

Proposition:

Let $S$ be a linear space and $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ two subspaces of $S$. Then, the sum $S_{1}+S_{2}$ is a subspace of $S$
Proof:

Randomly choose two vectors $s,t \in S_{1},S_{2}$. By the definition of the sum of two subspaces, there exist vectors $s_{1},t_{1} \in S_{1} $ and $s_{2},t_{2} \in S_{2}$ such that
$$
s=s_{1}+s_{2}
$$

and $t= t_{1}+t_{2}$.

Consider a linear combination of $s$ and $t$ with scalar coefficient $\sigma $ and $\gamma$
$$
\sigma s+ \gamma t= \sigma s_{1}+ \sigma s_{2} + \gamma t_{1}+ \gamma t_{2}
$$

$$
\sigma s_{1}+ \gamma t_{1} \in S_{1}
$$

and
$$
\sigma s_{2}+ \gamma t_{2} \in S_{2}
$$
Therefore, the linear combination $\sigma s+ \gamma t$ can be written as a sum of a vector of $S_{1}$

and a vector of $S_{2}$. Thus ,
$$
\sigma s+ \gamma t \in S_{1}+S_{2}
$$

In other words, $S_{1}+S_{2}$ is a linear subspace.

Definition(direct sum of subspaces):

Let $S$ be a linear space. Let $S_{1},\dots,S_{n}$ be subspaces of $S$. The sum $s_{1}+ \dots + s_{n}$ is called direct sum and is donated by
$$
s_{1} \oplus s_{2} \dots s_{n}
$$
or
$$
\bigoplus_{i=1}^{n}s_{i}
$$

if and only if $s_{1}+ \dots + s_{n}$ are linearly independent whenever $s_{j} \in S_{j}$ and $s_{j} \ne 0$ for $j=1, \dots , n$

Proposition:

Let $S$ be a linear space. Let $s_{1}+ \dots +s_{n}$ be a direct sum if and only if the unique way to obtain
$$
s_{1}+\dots s_{n} =0 (s_{j} \in S{j}, j=1,2 \dots ,n)
$$
is to set $s_{1}=0 , \dots ,s_{n}=0$

Proof:

entry.title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
entry.content:
Fundamental theorem of calculus:

First:
$$
\int_{a}^{b}f(x)dx=F(b)-F(a)
$$
when $F’(x)=f(x)$ and $F(x)$ is continuous on $[a,b]$

Second:

when
$$
\int_{a}^{x}f(t)dt=g(x)
$$
and f(x) is continuous on $[a,b]$ and $x \in [a,b]$

then $g’(x)=f(x)$

it can also be written as $\frac{\int^{x}_{a}f(t)dt}{dx}=f(x)$

entry.title: reduced-echelon-form
entry.content:
Definition (row echelon form):

  1. all its non-zero rows have an entry, called the pivot, that is non-zero and has only zero entries below it and to its left.
  2. zero-rows (if there are any) are below the non-zero rows.

Example:

{% mathjax %}\begin{bmatrix}1 \ 0 \ 0\\0 \ 3 \ 0 \\0 \ 0 \ 0 \end{bmatrix}{% endmathjax %}

is a matrix of row echelon form.

Definition(reduced row echelon form):

A matrix is in reduced row echelon form if and only if it is in a row reduced echelon form, all its pivots are equal to 1 and the pivots are the only non-zero entries of the basic columns.

Example:

{% mathjax %}\begin{bmatrix} 0 \ 1 \ 3 \ 3 \\ 0 \ 0 \ 1 \ 0 \end{bmatrix}{% endmathjax %}

is in row echelon form because both of its rows have a pivot, however, it is hot in reduced row echelon form because there is a non-zero entry in the column of the pivots $A_{23}$

How to solve a system in reduced echelon form

Consider a linear form

$$
Ax=b
$$

where $A$ is a $K \times L$ matrix of coefficients, $x$ is an $L \times 1$ vector of unknowns, and $b$ is a $K \times 1$ vector of constants.

The system is said to be in reduced row echelon form if the matrix $A$ is in reduced row echelon form.

Since the reduced echelon form is a special case of the echelon form, the conditions for the existence of a solution of a system in the form apply, and we can use the back-substitution algorithm to solve the problem.

If an unknown multiplies a basic column, it is called a basic variable. Otherwise, if it corresponds to a non-basic column, it is called a non-basic variable.

Since the reduced echelon form is a special case of the echelon form, we can use the back-substitution algorithm to solve that problem.
